## DNA Sequence Analysis - Part One

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
Sequences_data<-read.table("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/EmiliagG/Rentrez/main/Sequences.csv", header=T, sep="," )
library(dplyr)

#print each sequence 
print("Sequence 1: HQ433692.1, B.Burgdorferi")
print(Sequences_data$Sequence[1])
print("Sequence 2: HQ433694.1, B.Burgdorferi")
print(Sequences_data$Sequence[2])
print("Sequence 3: HQ433691.1, B.Burgdorferi ")
print(Sequences_data$Sequence[3])

#counting the number of base pairs in each sequence 
A_bp<-c()
T_bp<-c()
G_bp<-c() 
C_bp <-c()

for(item in Sequences_data$Sequence){
    A_bp<-c(A_bp, nchar(gsub("[^A]","",item)))
    T_bp<-c(T_bp, nchar(gsub("[^T]", "", item)))
    G_bp<-c(G_bp, nchar(gsub("[^G]", "", item)))
    C_bp<-c(C_bp, nchar(gsub("[^C]", "", item)))
}

SequenceID=c("HQ433692.1","HQ433694.1","HQ433691.1")

no_bp<-data.frame(SequenceID=SequenceID,
                  A=A_bp,T=T_bp,G=G_bp,C=C_bp)

print(no_bp)

#calculate the total number of bp in each sequence
total_bp<-c()
for (item in Sequences_data$Sequence) {
  total_bp<-c(total_bp, nchar(item))
}

#calculate GC_Content
GC<-no_bp %>%
  group_by(SequenceID) %>%
  summarize(GC_Content=(round(((sum(G,C)/481)*100),digits=2)))
colnames(GC)[2]<-"GC Content (%)"
print(GC)

```

#Part Two

```{r, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(BiocManager)
library(annotate)
library(dplyr)

unknownSeq<-read.delim("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/EmiliagG/Rentrez/main/UknownSeq.fa.txt")
#str(unknownSeq)
#head(unknownSeq$X..Human.isolate..unknown.sequence)

unknownSeq2<-paste(unknownSeq$X..Human.isolate..unknown.sequence[1], 
                   unknownSeq$X..Human.isolate..unknown.sequence[2], 
                   unknownSeq$X..Human.isolate..unknown.sequence[3],
                   unknownSeq$X..Human.isolate..unknown.sequence[4],
                   unknownSeq$X..Human.isolate..unknown.sequence[5])
#unknownSeq2
unknownSeq2<-gsub(" ", "", unknownSeq2)
#unknownSeq2

unknownBlastDF<-blastSequences(unknownSeq2,hitListSize=50,
                               as='data.frame',timeout=5000)
#nrow(unknownBlastDF)
str(unknownBlastDF)
hits1<-unknownBlastDF %>%
  group_by(Hit_def) %>%
  summarize(Hsp_evalue)
#hits1

hits2<-unknownBlastDF %>%
  group_by(Hit_def) %>%
  summarize(Hsp_score)
#hits2

matchDNA<-(unknownBlastDF$Hsp_hseq[1])
matchDNAString<-DNAString(matchDNA)
unknownDNA<-DNAString(unknownSeq2)

matchDNAString
unknownDNA

unknownBlastDF %>%
  group_by(Hit_accession) %>%
  summarize(Hit_def,Hsp_score, Hsp_evalue, Hsp_gaps)

#not sure why all the values are the same...the code seems to be identical for all these IDs in GenBank. 

```
Table 1. Output of the blastSequences (blastn) search of GenBank to identify a match the unknown DNA strand (n=326). 

Using Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) there is evidence the unknown DNA sequence provided to the Canadian Public Health Agency is a strain of *Yersinia pestis*. *Y.pestis* is the bacteria responsible for Plague, known in European history as the "Black Death," making this an infection of high concern ().Comparing the unknown DNA sequence to sequeces in NCBI's GenBank revealed over 300 matches with zero gaps between the query sequence and the GenBank matches, and high-scoring segment pair values of 500 (Table 1). 

Reference
Harvard Health Publishing.(2024, May 21). *Plague (Yersinia Pestis)*. Accessed at:  https://www.health.harvard.edu/a_to_z/plague-yersinia-pestis-a-to-z
